subject: Re: [junit] Re: How do I submit code which I think should be added to JUnit?
msgSnippet: ... I d like to add two aspects: - JUnit should be the stable angle for the very unstable projects we all have to do. Changing too much jeopardizes stableness.
messageBody:
> 2. JUnit as a political gesture celebrates the ability of programmers
> to test their own software. The code and tests must be held to a
> higher standard, to demonstrate the techniques necessary to uphold
> our end of the bargain.

I'd like to add two aspects:
- JUnit should be the stable angle for the very unstable projects we all
have to do. Changing too much jeopardizes stableness.
- When adding too much non-core functionality one quickly looses focus of
the core parts. Very often the extra functionality is not exactly what I
need in a specific situation, so I have to reimplement it anyway. If the
unneeded and unwanted part of a tool is prevailing many will move towards
starting from scratch with a new (small) framework. That's why I'd rather
have JUnit as a core with hooks to plug in additional behaviour which is
available in additional tools.

BTW, is the move to version 4 as described in
http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?JunitNextRelease
an "official" thing, i.e. promoted by Kent and Erich?

Johannes
